info.game_comments:
1997 Power Players Week game 4.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: The Rockettes get a kick out of the art deco lobby in this New York theater, their home

(2, 1).clue: This team's logo is on champagne bottles commemorating the opening of Jack Kent Cooke Stadium

(3, 1).clue: In 1883 he opened his Wild West Show in Omaha, Nebraska

(4, 1).clue: Henry Perky turned out his first batch of this cereal in 1892; in 1928 Nabisco bought his company

(5, 1).clue: The Celibate Rifles chose their name as a counterpart to this British punk band's

(6, 1).clue: If it fits, "wear it", but hope it's not "on the other foot"

(1, 2).clue: Live alligators were once featured in the lobby of the Jefferson Hotel in this Virginia capital

(2, 2).clue: On May 15, 1997 the NBA's Washington Bullets took this name

(3, 2).clue: In 1997 he broke Jack Nicklaus' 32-year-old Masters record of 17 under par

(4, 2).clue: As a whole, its head can be stuffed; shredded, it can be a slaw

(5, 2).clue: The name of this Florida band combines a blonde actress & the head of a "murderous" family

(1, 3).clue: You may see sharks swimming in the lobby aquarium in this Las Vegas hotel named for a desert illusion

(2, 3).clue: Ron Wilson, the former head coach of the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim, now coaches this team

(3, 3).clue: In the victory column, this Alabamian has 4 more than Pop Warner

(4, 3).clue: This shredded substance puts the queso in a quesadilla

(5, 3).clue: The song heard here was a 1989 Top 10 single for this group:

(1, 4).clue: Twice a day, these web-footed birds march through the lobby of the Peabody Hotel in Memphis

(2, 4).clue: The D.C. United plays this sport outside while the Warthogs play it indoors

(3, 4).clue: On "Another Saturday Night" you'll find him "Sitting" on a "Peace Train" until "Morning Has Broken"

(2, 5).clue: Before moving, this baseball team was called, "First in War, First in Peace & Last in the American League"

(3, 5).clue: This "Good Morning, Vietnam" star once studied drama with John Houseman

(1, 1).clue: Former senators Alan Simpson & this man co-chair Project Independence to reform campaign finances

(2, 1).clue: When Lex gets hungry & bored, he toasts marshmallows over this gas device named for a German chemist

(3, 1).clue: In 1993 he was "In the Line of Fire" as Secret Service agent Frank Horrigan

(4, 1).clue: An easy one of our English rhymes: Henry VIII wed this many times

(5, 1).clue: He was nicknamed "Red" as a child, but you know him better as "Silent Cal"

(6, 1).clue: Once meaning "lacking religious beliefs", it now means cheating on your spouse

(1, 2).clue: Bob Chase, the president of this teachers' union, has a regular column in the Washington Post

(3, 2).clue: This star of "Grumpy Old Men" played a grumpy Supreme Court justice in "First Monday in October"

(4, 2).clue: A "Major" change was the designation, so Britain accepted her '90 resignation

(5, 2).clue: As a youth, this Georgian was nicknamed "Hot", short for "Hot Shot"

(6, 2).clue: It once meant "an insult", so you'd be adding insult to...insult

(3, 3).clue: Laurence Harvey & Frank Sinatra starred in this 1962 political thriller based on a novel by Richard Condon

(4, 3).clue: In 1788 convicts were bound for this big land that Cook had found

(5, 3).clue: William McKinley was known as the "Idol of" this Buckeye state, his birthplace

(6, 3).clue: Now it's a den in which you'd find an animal lion around; a long time ago, it was "a coach"

(3, 4).clue: In "All the President's Men", Hal Holbrook played this informer whose true identity is still a mystery

(4, 4).clue: In '43 this prime minister man was one of the Big 3 who met in Teheran

(5, 4).clue: Men who slandered his wife Rachel found out quickly why he was called the "Duel Fighter"

(6, 4).clue: It was a tavern, or a clump of ivy hung on a pub; today it's a small shrub, or an ex-president

(3, 5).clue: This British actor, JFK's brother-in-law, played a U.S. senator in "Advise and Consent"

(5, 5).clue: This "Bachelor President" was affectionately nicknamed "Old Buck"

(6, 5).clue: Henry, Jane, Peter or Bridget might tell you that this 4-letter word once meant "foolish"

(0, 0).clue: The Italian name of this 15th century masterpiece is "L'Ultima Cena"
